instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 9V on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Water damaged near SMC. This one had no backlight issue (no bklt boosting because no PWM signal) because of <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> partially shorted to ground on SMC (only 1.24V).

Replaced the SMC and now it works but <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 9V!

Tried a reflow and made sure the smc "dance trick" but nothing change, still 9V, i am confident with soldering.

Backlight now works because hell <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is high now... did'nt tried yet if <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> come back low when lid is closed...

SMC seems alive, charging battery with orange light and ASD EFI report no errors.
I must admit this particular SMC came from china...

Have you had something similar? Any thoughts before i replace smc from a donour board.

Thanks

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 9V on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>
threads.message: There is no voltage higher than 3v3 around the SMC so impossible for this problem to come from the SMC. More likely is a short/leak in the board. Check if <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> goes low when lid closed.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 9V on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You are right internal short.

<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> goes low to 0.124V when lid is closed... Seems to work normally but for how long :(

Unfortunately I don't see any tracks at <TRANSISTOR>Q5701</TRANSISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R6961</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> goes right away through the board. It would be easy to recreate the circuit but the problem are the traces not accessible.
I thought maybe using pin 112 on smc and isolate <SIGNAL>USB_DEBUGPRT_EN_L</SIGNAL> it is adjacent to pin 111 but don't think worth the try.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 9V on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>
threads.message: It works, just pray that it doesn't return.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 9V on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I will pray for it :)
Post can be closed thanks.
